Agreement on sufficient progress hung in the balance this week as DUP concerns about the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland scuppered a deal on Monday. Compromise was reached overnight after talks between PM May and the Irish government/DUP and additional language was inserted guaranteeing no border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain.
Other aspects of the agreement represent a capitulation from the UK side on almost all key sticking points, including the financial settlement (with the UK committing to EU structural funds with a cut-off date of end-2020) and citizens rights (with ECJ jurisdiction over rights continuing after the date of exit, although time limited by eight years).
Most importantly, the language on Northern Ireland commits the UK to continued regulatory alignment with the EU after the date of exit 'in the absence of other agreed solutions.' While regulatory alignment only concerns areas of cooperation under the Good Friday Agreement, its broad coverage would effectively commit the UK to many aspects of EU membership as a default option after the date of exit. This would limit the ability of the UK to conduct third country free trade deals and may be seen unfavorably by Brexiteers in government

BE11:09am

Brexit talks will continue to be highly relevant for the UK outlook and attention will turn to the prospects of a transitional deal in the New Year. The EU27 will provide Barnier a mandate to conduct talks over transition. The question is to what extent early agreement is possible (at the latest, the UK needs this by the end of March), and how contingent any agreement is made on the outcome of talks on a future relationship. This could be tricky and the UK's options are explored in a report here. Information from next week's Council will need to be scrutinized closely.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The result of this week's talks has also been to crystallize existing divisions within the Conservative Party over Brexit. Prime Minister May had hoped to defer a decision about the UK's long-term relationship with the EU until after securing a transitional deal early in the New Year. The need to solve the puzzle over Northern Ireland has forced May to reach consensus on the future relationship earlier. As the cabinet and Conservative Party are divided, the risk has increased that this leads to a break-up in the government.

BE11:09am

Only if an early transition can be agreed, effectively delaying Brexit until 2021, can the focus turn back to fundamentals. On the policy front, the market may price more from the Bank of England, not least as Governor Carney said that a recalibration of monetary policy would be warranted once agreement on transition was reached. But we do not expect a modification of policy based on today's agreement from the Bank of England next week.
In sum, today marks the beginning of the end of the Brexit process. Time is the UK's most precious commodity going forward and the UK cannot afford more delays.

The most important thing we heard from Jean Claude Juncker in the press conference is that he wants to start negotiating the transition deal immediately. This was backed up by Donald Tusk. Why does this matter? If the UK and EU can quickly agree a transition deal of at least two years in Q1 2018 then we will have three years until any major changes happen because of Brexit. This takes it beyond the scope of the market or MPC to really worry about. In other words, the key change next year is that the market’s sensitivity to Brexit negotiations should fall substantially – and stop weighing so much on UK yields and GBP.

BE11:19am

Moves we expect into year-end

It’s not lost on us that at the start of this year when Theresa May delivered her “hard Brexit” Lancaster House speech that GBP rallied 3% that day. Markets are not always rational. So after today’s progress GBP has yet to materially move higher. This is not a product of outcome vs expectations (as hopes of progress had been diminishing over recent days), but that vs positioning where the market is clearly long gamma with one-week GBP/USD vol still extended at 11.2 (falling from a 13.5 high).

This is why we expect the move to be gradual rather than a knee-jerk reaction as short-term market participants already have long GBP positions according to our position report. Even so, we expect a move above 1.36 in GBP/USD today. We then expect GBP/USD to reach 1.40 into and through the New Year while EUR/GBP has already broken below our 0.87 target. However, we prefer to let our short position continue to run into the New Year and see a return to the 0.84/0.86 range.

Likewise, we expect Gilt yields to rise into year-end. The news today is one catalyst but, as with FX, we think yields may continue grinding higher, potentially helped if some hawkish risks around the MPC materialise next week. We also note that December (lack of) liquidity can make moves larger than fundamentals might imply at this time of year.

Another strong set of results were tempered by some cautious noises about the London market, unsurprisingly. At the same time, the group has upped its profit guidance for the five-year period to April 2021 – as we expected. We continue to believe the target remains very conservative given the strength of the land bank. Still a Buy.

BE11:26am

First-half profits were strong, with PBT up 36% at £533m on revenue up 14% on the back of 2% more completions (at 2,117). Operating margins jumped to 31.8% from 27.7%, as a result of a sharp drop in overhead costs (linked to the LTIP payments). The NAV has increased 15% since April at £17.85. As expected, forward sales dropped a little to £2.45bn from £2.74bn in April. The group has bought back 2.7m shares at a cost of £93m, which will be taken into account when making the dividend payment.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

The group finished the first half with net cash of
£632m, up from £286m six months ago. Land holdings edged lower, with 32,916 plots on the balance sheet at October vs 33,771 at April 2017. The group has a further 12,895 plots, which are contracted awaiting planning or vacant possession. The group bought five new sites in the period – two in the new Midlands/Birmingham business, one in Camberley, one at the Oval and one at Highbury through its St William JV.

BE11:27am

Outlook & forecasts. The group has increased its five-year profit target to £3.3bn from £3bn, with £1.5bn expected to be delivered in the two years to April 2019 (our expectations were top end at £1.48bn). The group retains a degree of caution with regards to investment in new sites on the back of the uncertain economic environment. Margins are expected to move lower over time from the current levels. Recent sales have been okay, with reservations on an annual basis 20% up on last year but 10% down on 2015/16. Our five-year forecast number remains above (£3.6bn) the group's guidance as we continue to believe the group is being overly cautious.

BE11:27am

Performance & valuation. The shares have performed well in 2017 with a rally of 43% ytd, nearly 10% ahead of the sector average. We continue to see good long-term value in the business, with the growth in NAV combined with the expected dividend payments offering good medium-term returns for investors. We remain unfazed by the management share sales and retain our long-term Buy recommendation.

It’s a funny old game. This quick note started as a catch-up on what Poundland was up to: the new chief there spoke very expansively in this week’s Retail Week and some of his ideas are eye-opening (£99 mattresses in 20 stores at present) and relevant to B&M (multiple pricing makes it a more credible competitor). However, the Steinhoff problems put the boot firmly on the other foot and mean that Poundland’s status is now in a state of flux (SNH is looking to raise €1bn in disposals in short order). It’s impossible to imagine that major strategic change will be able to occur as things stand at the parent. Would B&M be interested in Poundland? Almost certainly not: the stores don’t really conform to its model, but anything’s possible if the price is right. As for B&M itself, we have no doubt that it is currently trading very well, and problems at Poundland and closures at category killers such as Toys R Us will only help further in the medium term. The shares have held up OK relative to the retail sector, but we expect consensus to rise (possibly across a strong Christmas trading statement), and a 16x PE looks like good value to us. SNH’s other assets in the UK are Bensons for Beds and Harveys. The latter operates in a part of the market that has seen consolidation of late, so a trade sale is not impossible there.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Ambitious plans for Poundland…: Life under Steinhoff hasn’t been easy for Poundland, but in his first press interview (Retail Week), the new boss there expressed aggressive strategic plans for the chain. Most headline-grabbing was the plan to move away from the single price point. And we aren’t just talking about £2 and £3 items: at the moment 20 stores are selling £99 “mattresses in a bag” (side point, how do you bring it back?). Already more than 100 Poundland stores have Pep&Co clothing implants, and the plan was to take this to over 300. There was even talk of offering an in-store loan proposition. We argued at length, with manifold references to Dollarama in Canada, that Poundland should have done something like this years ago. It is the right strategy and would make it a stronger competitor for the other discounters. It also intends to roll the Dealz fascia out to hundreds of locations across Europe

BE11:39am

… are now today’s chip paper: The problems at Steinhoff have prompted a chain of events that make any major strategic progress at Poundland very unlikely. Some of the ongoing changes, such as multiple pricing, will surely continue to be implemented, but a hefty capex plan will be shelved. It would appear that pretty much everything in the SNH stable is up for sale. Would anyone in the trade be interested in taking Poundland on in its entirety? It’s unlikely, we think. There are doubtless a good number of sites that B&M and Home Bargains would like to get hold of, but both have strong new store pipelines anyway. It is a fire sale though, and anything is possible if the price fell far enough, but BME/PLND is long odds against, we think…
